content: Can remember a instance when a woman in an apartment complex went into her bathroom and found a large python or boa in her toilet. It had evidently used the sewer system as an avenue of approach from the apartment above. Of course there have been instances where large "pet" snakes have crawled into cribs and killed toddlers. An old lady kept calling into the local police station that there was a large snake terrorizing her and her pets, and it was living under her house. Because snakes are common there (we had a small one of some kind that occasionally appeared out of a hole in the far corner of our back yard), the police weren't in any hurry to check it out. She finally called and said they needed to do something about it because it had just killed the neighbor's dog - - Well, that finally got them to show up, but they were still pretty skeptical. Because of the content of her call, the local TV station decided to tag along, so it was on the evening news. One of the officers/animal control people crawled down under the house, which was built on about 2 foot high pylons with slat skirting to keep critters out, but there was a large gap torn out. Suddenly the officer started yelling that he needed help, and 3 or 4 more crawled down in... After a moment, they came out dragging a Python that was very well 20 feet or longer and several hundred pound! It's head looked to me as big as a small football, and in the center of the critter's body was a very large bulge that was most likely the neighbor's dog - - Incidents like these might have something to do with why people are leery about you have reptiles about - - Wandering and Wondering

content: Both of my parents were/are quick to kill snakes. I'm not. They were raised in times and under conditions where the territory of the Wild and the territory of the Civilized was still in dispute. Stories of snakes - both dangerous and maybe not - coming into rude 1920s homes through cracks in walls or up through knot holes in the flooring, causing shock, fright, and terror are pretty common in their lore. Finding themselves in close proximity with "joe no-shoulders" while working in a field, walking a path to the out-house, or some other circumstance, created a certain sense of instant panic and immediate reaction that meant only one thing - survival. They had cats to get rid of vermin, so the snake any snake, had to go, for the sake of the safety of the family. Here are three typical stories to illustrate their fears and reasons: Dad was a cowboy in the 1920s. Automobiles were not even in use in southern Utah yet. He was riding along in a gully looking for stray cattle. The bank of the gully was about 3 or 4 feet high. He felt something brushing back and forth on his boot, looked down, and a large rattler was hanging by its fangs from his pant-leg, it venom trickling down the side of his boot. He reached down quickly and threw it off, then emptied his .44 pistol into it. He also had a Bulldog called "Mugsie" which often tangled with rattlers. content: Both of my parents were/are quick to kill snakes. I'm not. They were raised in times and under conditions where the territory of the Wild and the territory of the Civilized was still in dispute. Stories of snakes - both dangerous and maybe not - coming into rude 1920s homes through cracks in walls or up through knot holes in the flooring, causing shock, fright, and terror are pretty common in their lore. Finding themselves in close proximity with "joe no-shoulders" while working in a field, walking a path to the out-house, or some other circumstance, created a certain sense of instant panic and immediate reaction that meant only one thing - survival. They had cats to get rid of vermin, so the snake any snake, had to go, for the sake of the safety of the family. Here are three typical stories to illustrate their fears and reasons: Dad was a cowboy in the 1920s. Automobiles were not even in use in southern Utah yet. He was riding along in a gully looking for stray cattle. The bank of the gully was about 3 or 4 feet high. He felt something brushing back and forth on his boot, looked down, and a large rattler was hanging by its fangs from his pant-leg, it venom trickling down the side of his boot. He reached down quickly and threw it off, then emptied his .44 pistol into it. He also had a Bulldog called "Mugsie" which often tangled with rattlers. It would circle the snake until the reptile would try to crawl away, then it would dive in an shake the serpent to pieces. They kept the dog around the younger children to protect them from snakes, and it was bit several times, often getting very sick. Eventually, it died from a bite. They often turned pigs loose, because pigs would eat snakes. Then the ranchers would hunt and eat the pigs - so it went. Snakes are somewhat scare there now... Mom tells a story of going outside to check on my older sisters at play and found the oldest sister, about 4 at the time, sitting on the ground watching a rattler that was coiled not too far away. The ever-present irrigation shovel went into full gear! I have had several very close calls with rattlers. One came up behind me out of a beaver lodge I was standing on while fishing, and started buzzing - thank goodness. I had to jump in the water to get away from it. Friends with me killed it... I have killed numerous rattlers, but I have saved a few too. The reason? One I killed on the desert had three mice inside when I skinned it... A time later, I saw a very large one slowly crossing a well-traveled dirt road out in the desert, so I decided to stop, get out my walking stick, pick it up, and get it to the bushes on the side. It buzzed angrily at me through the whole process, but never struck. Just as I finished, a huge truck came through which would certainly have run over it - - As I get much older, I am less comfortable with taking the life of almost anything, because anything trying to survive these days probably has the right to go on trying - - Here is a poem I wrote a long, long time ago - - 13 March 82 - - - -The End of March - - - - I walked along and looked down, And he looked back at me; He used his comical yellow eye, And he rustled the grass As he went down the bank. Then he stopped at the water’s edge; His head turned ‘round, And he said to me - - “You were young once. Your eyes were bright one time.” I heard his small whispering voice Coming up to me from that Flickering tongue, those tight lips; And I went down to talk to him. But he only laughed And smiled a shiny, plated smile. I picked him up in my hand, But he had said his say. His yellow eye mocked me; Like a mean little boy, He stuck his tongue out at me - - I smiled and dropped him Into the creek as I would have Any mischievous friend, And he swam quickly away. But he had the last laugh; He stopped on the far bank And turned back with a prideful look; Then he said to me - - “You are old now! You should do the things Old ones do.” I tried to answer, But he did not wait for me - - I climbed back up to the road And walked slow back to town. Wandering and Wondering
